title: Two pipes can fill an empty tank in 40 minutes and in 60 minutes respectively. If both are opened at once, how long will it take to fill the tank? - Quora

response.answer_text: For all such questions,even for n pipes.. Step1..think unit time work each.. IE what amount one alone can fill in unit time.. IE 1/40 part n other 1/60. Similarly if n pipes till 1/n(i) Step2..what if all work for unit time ie sum of all unit.. IE (1/40+1/60) =(60+40)/60*40=1/24 part if both works for unit time.. Similarly if n pipes.. (1/40)+(1/60)+. +..+…..till 1/n(i)..let it be m/n Step3..now it's child play.. U know part per unit time ie filled by all.. So to fill full part (IE 1) =whole part /part per day=1/(1/24)=24 days.. ie your answer... If for n pipes, simply it's 1/(m/n)=n/m days.. Either that's is pipes, labour or whatever ;such type problems are solved in similar ways..

To make the maths easier. and because you did not specify the size/volume of the tank, I am going to make an assumption that the tank holds 6,000 litres of water. Now let tap A fill the tank in 40 minutes and tap B can fill the tank in 60 minutes. Let A and B be the flow rates of tap A and tap B respectively. And let t be the time taken to fill the tank Then . . . . A = 6000 L/40 mins A = 150 L/min B = 6000L/60 mins B = 100L/min Therefore, when both taps are on, the combined flow rate will be A + B = 150L/min + 100L/min A + B = 250L/min Time to fill tank . . . . t = 6000L / (250L/min) t = 24 minutes

Assume tank as A Pipe 1 can fill tank A in 40 minutes and in 1 minute it can fill A / 40 th part, Pipe 2 can fill the same tank A in 60 minutes and in 1 minute it can fill A / 60 th part , If both are opened then in 1 minute they both can fill ((A / 40)+(A / 60)) th part. After solving the above equation you will get (A / 24) which means in 1 minute it can fill 1/24 th part and to fill the complete tank it takes 24 minutes. Thank you.

I have developed a fundamental equation for this and let me repeat it. Let Z= volume of the tank. Let X and Y be the respective time to fill the tank by the 2 pipes Then flow rate for the pipes are Z/X and Z/Y respectively. If both pipes are linked to the tank simultaneously then the flow rateF is F=Z/X+Z/Y= Z(X+Y)/XY Recall time T = Z/Flow rate or XY/X+Y Substituting 40×60/40+ 60 Your answer will be 24 minutes.

Assume the tank holds x gallons, then one pipe will deliver x/40 gal/min and the other x/60 gal/min. Together they will deliver x/40 + x/60 gal/min. Therefore the time to fill the tank Will be x/(x/40 + x/60)= 24 minutes. Note: the answer is independent of the volume of the tank.

First pipe in 1 minute fills 1/40 of tank Second fills in 1 minute 1/60 of tank Together in 1 minute they fill 1/40 +1/60 = 5/120 = 1/24 of tank ANSWER 24 minutes SHORT CUT METHOD PRODUCT / SUM = 60*40/(60+40) =2400/100 =24 minutes

The speed of pipe A is 1,5 tanks per hour, the speed of pipe B is 1 tank/h. We need to find the time t needed to fill the tank by the two pipes which comes from the following equation which says that in time t, one tank is filled: 1,5t + 1t = 1 2,5t = 1 t = 1 / 2,5 = 0,4 So the time is 0,4 h which is 0,4 * 60 = 24 min.
